posts.name: Bahni Roy
posts.cooked:
@carlton You can use this example as well, as I have the same observation.
There are 3623 eateries in the spreadsheet, so number of pairs is 3623 C 2 which is 6,561,253 pairs (so that would be the upperbound of the answer for any variant of this question using this spreadsheet with different vaues for the distance that can vary from question to question). As you can see in the options below, all of the 4 answers exceed this upperbound. My computed answer is a 6 digit number (cross verified with GPT 4 and Claude Sonnet just to be sure).

In eateries.csv, count the number of pairs of eateries within 558 meters of the each other.

You need to find the distance between every pair of eateries and count the number of pairs that are within the given distance.
6,778,391
6,778,411
6,778,421
6,778,401

posts.name: Bahni Roy
posts.cooked:
I would say, Q7 should be excluded since the options are incorrect.

Doubling will match one of the options, but thats more of a technical manipulation and in itself, any technical adjustment do not necessarily make the options correct in the first place (a prerequisite for the question to be considered valid). The options, being incorrect, are null and void.

If a student selects BDM and TDS in one term, we do not interpret (or say) that the student has selected two pairs of subjects (BDM, TDS) and (TDS, BDM) because, the usual interpretation is that 2 pairs of subjects mean 4 distinct subjects in total. We interpret that (and say), the student has selected a pair of subjects. The same interpretation should hold true for Q7 as well.

posts.name: Adith SR
posts.cooked: I agree, and I also believe Q7 should be excluded. I had just mentioned it to be extra safe, but like you said, that should not be a requirement.
